{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3414939,"name":"Alon Shaul ","username":"alonshaul","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/alonshaul/{size}/231347_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-12T19:05:31.220Z","cooked":"

Hi I’m alon and I am in a robotics team (like all of us) and I am also an artist. I recently found out that my team working on a real new robot and they asked me to help but I don’t have a lot of time because I’m working on a very hard art pice and I don’t know what to chose any advice?

Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-12T21:25:14.592Z","cooked":"

They asked you, which is nice of them, but doesn’t create an obligation on your part. If you would rather work on the art piece and can’t do both, tell them thanks for asking, but that you’re not able to help (or only able to help in a specific small amount, or only able to help starting in November, or whatever the case is).
You will have many people asking for your time or other limited resources across your life and you can’t say “yes” to everything.

One thing that I’ve sometimes used is a “regret minimization framework”:

Imagine it’s 2026 and both the art project and this new robot are in the history books (or never accomplished). Would you regret more not doing the art project, not working on the robot, or doing a half-great job on both projects? (This is just a simple mental “trick” that restates your own question, but in that restating, it sometimes helps clarify which answer you’d prefer [or might just rule out one of the possibilities].)
